title: Should I write a thank you email after receiving a job rejection email? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let me begin by saying that the comments that follow assume that your rejection followed an interview. If the process didn’t get that far, it probably won’t even get past their spam filter. If you’re going to send a thank you note, there has to be something you can say thank you for, doesn’t there? But let’s assume you did at least get an interview. Even though it’s always a disappointment not to be offered the job, a thank you letter is going to go down well, Ales. Let’s look at why it’s a good idea. To begin with, they won’t be expecting it because very few candidates will take the trouble to do so. Secondly, they were sufficiently impressed with your resume/C.V. to offer you an interview. In that sense, it wasn’t a rejection. You can thank them for that can’t you? Sending a thank you note leaves an impression that you’re a person with a positive attitude who can handle being turned down without getting all bitter and twisted about it. There’s every chance that they will keep your name on file for when they have another vacancy in the future. Finally, to make sure that your thank you note doesn’t get spam-filtered, I’d suggest sending it as a letter addressed to your interviewer rather than email.

You certainly don't have to but it can be a nice thing to do. This is assuming you're talking about an email from an actual person (vs. an automated response.) So few people even bother to do the bare minimum courtesy of letting someone know they weren't hired, and it actually takes some time on the part of the person who sent you the rejection letter, so I think it's worth acknowledging that they did something they didn't strictly have to do for you. So I'd just say, “I'm disappointed of course, but I sincerely appreciate your taking the time to let me know.” This does two things: it acknowledges the effort they put in, and it will probably help you to feel that you're being classy and taking the high road.

Yes I would recommend it.  Someone did it to me once and the person we hired was lousy and quit after 2 weeks.  We went back to the candidate who had sent a thank you email and hired them.  They were great! If it had not been for that thank you email, we would probably have readvertised the job. People always appreciate being thanked and while it might not get you the job now, you might find that if you apply to them in the future, your name "stands out" to the hiring manager and you get given another shot.

It depends-did you go through the interview process? Then yes, since another position could open up in the future or you could end up working with some of these people down the line. Be honest "I'm sad to hear that I didn't make the cut, but I'm sure you've done what is best for the role." If you haven't interviewed, then this is a form letter, and I wouldn't write an email, but if you've met staffers, and developed a repore, it's ok to go the extra step and write a thank you note.

It never hurts to be kind! You could consider writing an email in return that thanks them for considering your application for the job. That while you are disappointed it did not work out, the very fact that they let you know, and did not leave you wondering is a big plus. The fact is that people who respond with kindness in the face of disappointment says a lot about their character, and a company looking to hire someone might consider someone who stands out with kindness.

If you applied online and got a standard rejection letter from a large company. I wouldn’t bother. On the other hand, if you went through the interview process, then absolutely send a short thank you note. It may be that someone in the interview process liked you and would consider you should another opportunity open up.

You can, but I strongly recommend against it. You honestly gain nothing from it. Maybe you can ask for feedback, but I guarantee that even if they respond - and odds are that they won’t - then they’ll give you some canned response about how the other candidate was a “better fit” for what they were seeking. Truth is that you’ll never know. Don’t waste you precious time. Trash the email.
